Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Multi-spectral Imaging Investigation of the Auroral Fine Structures Associated with Naturally Enhanced Ion Acoustic Lines
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is a synergistic study of radar and optical measurements for investigating and characterizing the occurrence of Naturally Enhanced Ion Acoustic Lines (NEIALs) with coincident auroral fine structures. While it is known that NEIALs are a manifestation of large-amplitude ion acoustic waves and potentially Langmuir waves and/or large current densities, their influence and feedback on the electromagnetic and particle energy transfer within the magnetosphere-ionosphere system is not well understood. The project will make use of common-volume observations of the nighttime auroral ionosphere with ground-based Electron Multiplying Charged Couple Device (EMCCD) imagers and the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR) to gain an improved understanding of NEIAL generation mechanisms. A suite of six narrowfield imagers will be used, each equipped with a different narrow bandpass filter, imaging multiple auroral emission lines simultaneously in order to derive the spatial distribution of the precipitating electron energy. The observations will take place during moon down periods, in both campaign and remote operation modes. The theory and modeling components will be investigated in partnership with an international collaborator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used simultaneous high-resolution low-light level imaging to observe the dynamic auroral structures that occur at the same time as anomalous backscattered returns in Incoherent Scatter Radar data, termed Naturally Enhanced Ion Acoustic Lines (NEIALs).  The use of multiple imagers, each with a different narrowband filter, allowed us to infer estimates of the precipitating electron characteristics.


Intellectual Merit:

We have found that there is a correlation between the type of aurora and the spectral and altitude characteristics of the NEIALs, which leads us to believe that it is possible to use the auroral structures to learn about the in situ processes that are creating the enhanced wave activity that leads to NEIALs in the radar data. We made initial estimates of the electron energy at the times of NEIALs and found that the altitude of where the NEIALs occurred was inversely proportional to the energy of the electrons.  


Broader Impacts:

This project has provided the opportunity to increase collaborations with colleagues in Europe who have experience with NEIALs using the EISCAT radars. The calibrating of the imager data and the computing of electron energy estimates has been a significant effort and provided programming and algorithm development for a graduate student who has been working with us.  The main results have been published a paper in Annales Geophysicae:


Michell, R. G., T. Grydeland, and M. Samara (2014). Characteristics of Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR) naturally enhanced ion-acoustic lines (NEIALs) in relation to auroral forms. Annales Geophysicae. 32 1333, doi:10.5194/angeo-32-1333-2014
